title-group.article-title: Bisphenol A Induces Oxidative Stress and Decreases Levels of Insulin Receptor Substrate 2 and Glucose Transporter 8 in Rat Testis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, School of Life Sciences, Pondicherry University, Pondicherry, India

author-notes.corresp: Premendu P. Mathur, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, School of Life Sciences, Pondicherry University, Pondicherry 605014, India Email: ppmathur@gmail.com

abstract.p: Bisphenol A (BPA), a monomer present in plastics, is known to impair male reproductive functions. Testis executes high-energy-demanding processes such as spermatogenesis and steroidogenesis, the successful accomplishment of which requires several factors including glucose. In this context, we sought to investigate the effects of low doses of BPA on glucose metabolism in the testis of rats and to delineate whether oxidative stress has any role to play in mediating the effects. Bisphenol A was orally administered to rats at dose levels of 0.005, 0.5, 50, and 500 µg/kg body weight for 45 days. A positive control was maintained by orally administering 17β-estradiol at a dose of 50 µg/kg body weight. The levels of plasma glucose and insulin were significantly increased, whereas the testicular glucose level significantly decreased following exposure to BPA and estradiol. A dose-dependent increase in the level of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and a significant decline in the activities of hexokinase and phosphofructokinase was observed in the testis of rats treated with BPA. Western blot analyses of insulin receptor substrate 2 (IRS-2) and glucose transporter 8 (GLUT-8) in the testis showed a decline in the levels of these proteins following BPA administration. Immunolocalization of GLUT-8 protein in the testis revealed decreased expression of this protein in spermatocytes and developing spermatids of rats exposed to BPA. The results suggest that persistent exposure to low doses of BPA could disturb glucose homeostasis in the testis and thereby impair testicular functions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bisphenol A (BPA) is an endocrine-disrupting monomer and it is used in polycarbonate plastics and epoxy resins. Of the several endocrine-disrupting chemicals, BPA has attained immense concern due to its widespread and continuous human exposure through various sources. Bisphenol A has been shown to induce various pathologic conditions such as cancers, neurological disorders, behavioral defects, developmental anomalies, and impaired fertility. 1 Testis is considered one of the highly sensitive targets for BPA-induced toxicity. The observed effects of BPA on testis include low sperm counts, decreased weight of testis, induction of oxidative stress, hormonal changes, and disruption of blood–testis barrier. 2 –4 However, recently, BPA has been suspected to be a diabetogenic agent. 5,6

Glucose has been shown to play an important role in the maintenance of normal reproductive functions. 7,8 Under normal conditions, the entry of glucose into the cells is facilitated by specific carrier proteins known as glucose transporters. In the testis, glucose transporter 8 (GLUT-8) appears to be the major carrier protein involved in the transport of glucose for maintaining normal testicular functions. 9 The cellular uptake of glucose into the cells by glucose transporters is accomplished by insulin, through receptor-mediated tyrosine phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrates (IRSs). Expression of IRSs-1, -2, and -3 has been demonstrated in human testis which indicates the plausible role of insulin on testicular functions. 10 Several factors are known to modify the expression of glucose transporters and IRSs in various tissues. 11,12 Oxidative stress has been shown to play a major and critical role in the impairment of insulin signaling and glucose homeostasis in different experimental models. 13,14 In addition, the oxidative stress-inducing capability of BPA in various tissues including testis has been well documented. 15,16 In our previous reports, we have shown that BPA induces oxidative stress in the epididymis and epididymal sperm of rats at a dose as low as 200 ng. 2,17 Several studies provide clear evidence for the low-dose effects of BPA on male reproduction. Despite being weakly estrogenic, BPA has been reported to be very potent even at low concentrations. Oral exposure to BPA at a dose of 20 µg/kg has been reported to reduce daily sperm production in rats within 6 days of exposure. 18 Similarly, a reduction in the daily sperm production was observed in the offsprings when pregnant mice were exposed to BPA at a dose of 20 ng. 19 Although BPA is a testicular toxicant and potent diabetogenic agent, it is not known whether exposure to low doses of BPA could impair glucose homeostasis and insulin signaling in testis of rats. Therefore, in the present study, we sought to investigate the effects of low doses of BPA on glycolytic enzymes, IRS-2 and GLUT-8, in the testis of rats and to delineate whether oxidative stress has any role to play in mediating the effects.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
Chemicals
sec.p: Bisphenol A (97% purity), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, fructose-6-phosphate, and glycerophosphate dehydrogenase were obtained from Sigma Chemical Company (St. Louis, Missouri). Goat polyclonal antibody raised against GLUT-8 (sc-14848), rabbit polyclonal antibody against IRS-2 (sc-8299), and rabbit polyclonal antibody against actin (sc-7210) were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, California). Horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG) was obtained from Bangalore Genei (Bangalore, India). All other chemicals used for various assays were of analytical grade and were obtained from local commercial source.

sec.title: Experimental Design
sec.p: Male rats of Wistar strain (90 days old) were obtained from Sri Ragavendra Enterprises, Bangalore, India. The animals were provided with standard laboratory chow and tap water ad libitum and were maintained at 24°C ± 2°C under a well-regulated dark and light (12 h:12 h) schedule. The experiments were carried out in accordance with the guidelines of the Committee for the Purpose of Control and Supervision on Experiments on Animals (CPCSEA), Government of India. 20

Animals were divided into 6 groups and 6 rats were maintained in each group. Bisphenol A was dissolved in olive oil and was administered by oral gavage for 45 consecutive days. Rats were exposed to a series of doses (lower than no observed effect level [NOAEL; 5 mg/kg per d] and the tolerable daily intake [TDI; 10 µg/kg per d] of BPA for humans 21 ) for 45 days (1 spermatogenic cycle) to determine whether BPA exerts its effects in a dose-dependent manner. Groups I, II, III, and IV received BPA dissolved in 1 mL of olive oil at the doses of 0.005, 0.5, 50, and 500 µg/kg body weight (bw), respectively. Control animals were administered olive oil alone (1 mL/kg bw). A positive control group was maintained by administering 17β-estradiol orally at a dose of 50 µg/kg bw. The dose of 17β-estradiol was selected based on a previous study which reported that 50 μg/kg bw estradiol exhibits effective estrogenic activity on testis. 22 Oral administration of estradiol was shown to have advantages over the parenteral routes for long-term experiments. 23 Hence, in the present study, 17β-estradiol was administered to rats by oral gavage.

The weights of the animals were monitored regularly till the end of the treatment. Twenty-four hours after the last dosing and overnight fasting (to estimate fasting plasma glucose and insulin levels), the animals were weighed and killed by cervical dislocation. Blood was drawn immediately by cardiac puncture and biochemical analysis was carried out in plasma. Testes were dissected out, weighed, and homogenized in cold normal saline with the help of glass-teflon homogenizer to obtain a 10% homogenate. The homogenates were centrifuged at 800g for 20 minutes at 4°C and the supernatants were collected. Protein was estimated by the method of Lowry et al 24 and the biochemical assays were carried out as described below.

sec.title: Evaluation of Fasting Plasma Glucose, Plasma Insulin, and Testicular Glucose Levels
sec.p: Plasma and testicular glucose levels were estimated by the glucose oxidase/peroxidase method as described by Trinder. 25 Plasma insulin concentration was measured using a rat enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) kit (Mercadia AB, Uppsala, Sweden).

sec.title: Evaluation of Oxidative Stress in the Testis
Hydrogen Peroxide Generation
sec.p: Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) generation was assayed by the method of Pick and Keisari. 26 Briefly, the incubation mixture containing 1.64 mL phosphate buffer (50 mmol/L, pH 7.6), 54 μL of horse radish peroxidase (8.5 units/mL), 30 μL of 0.28 nmol/L phenol red, 5.5 nmol/L of 165 μL of dextrose, and 600 μL of enzyme source were incubated at 32°C for 30 minutes. The reaction was terminated by the addition of 60 μL of 10 N sodium hydroxide. The absorbance was read at 610 nm against blank on a UV-Visible Spectrophotometer (UV-1700, Shimadzu, Japan). The quantity of H2O2 produced was expressed as µmol/min per mg protein. For the preparation of standard curve, known amount of H2O2 and all the above ingredients except enzyme source was incubated for 30 minutes at 32°C and then 60 μL of 10 N sodium hydroxide was added and the optical density was read at 610 nm.

sec.title: Evaluation of Glycolytic Enzymes in the Testis
Hexokinase
sec.p: The activity of hexokinase was assayed by the method of Bergmeyer and Walter. 27 Briefly, the reaction mixture contained 1 mL of 0.05 mol/L triethanolamine buffer pH 7.6, 1 mL of 0.555 mol/L d-glucose, 200 µL of 0.1 mol/L magnesium chloride (MgCl2), 200 µL of 0.014 mol/L nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP), 20 µL of 125 U/mL glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, and 200 µL of tissue homogenate; the reaction was then initiated by addition of 100 µL of 0.019 mol/L of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). The activity of enzyme was expressed as nmol of NADP reduced/min per mg protein.

sec.title: Phosphofructokinase
sec.p: The activity of phosphofructokinase was assayed after modification of the method of Narabayashi. 28 Briefly, the reaction mixture contained 2 mL of buffer that contained 50 mmol/L Tris/HCl (pH 8.0), 1 mmol/L fructose-6-phosphate, 1 mmol/L ATP, 2 mmol/L MgCl2, 0.16 mmol/L NADH, 2.6 mmol/L dithiothreitol, 1 mmol/L ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 5 mmol/L ammonium sulfate, 0.4 units aldolase, 2.5 units triose-P isomerase, and 0.4 units glycerophosphate dehydrogenase. The reaction was initiated by the addition of 100 µL of tissue homogenate and the decrease in absorbance was measured at 340 nm. The activity of enzyme was expressed as nmol of NADH oxidized/min per mg protein.

sec.title: Immunoblot Analysis of IRS-2 and GLUT-8 in the Testis
sec.p: Testis lysates were prepared separately in lysis buffer (50 mmol/L Tris, pH 7.4 containing 0.15 mol/L sodium chloride [NaCl], 10% glycerol [v/v], 1% NP-40 [v/v], 1 mmol/L sodium fluoride, 1 mmol/L sodium orthovanadate, 1 mmol/L phenylmethanesulfonylfluoride [PMSF], 1 mmol/L EDTA, 150 mmol/L bestatin, 1 mmol/L leupeptin, and 1 mmol/L aprotinin) using a tissue:buffer ratio of 1:5. After homogenization, the samples were centrifuged at 10 000g for 15 minutes and the supernatants were collected and stored at −70°C. The protein concentration was determined by Lowry method 24 and equal quantities of protein were loaded per lane and subjected to 10% sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (Mini Protean II System, Bio-Rad, Hercules, California) as described by Laemmli. 29 Electrophoresis was performed at 75 V and the resolved proteins were electophoretically transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane (NYTRAN, Keene, New Hampshire) in transfer buffer (0.2 mol/L glycine, 25 mmol/L Tris, and 20% methanol). Successful transfer was confirmed by Ponceau S staining of the blots. The membranes were incubated in blocking buffer (phosphate-buffered saline [PBS] containing 0.1% [v/v] Tween 20, and 5% [w/v] nonfat dry milk powder) for 5 hours at room temperature followed by incubation in respective primary antibodies (IRS-2 and GLUT-8 at 1:1000 dilutions). The incubation with the primary antibodies was carried out overnight at 4°C. The following day, the blots were washed in PBS and incubated for 1 hour at room temperature with either horseradish peroxidase conjugated anti-rabbit IgG or anti-goat IgG (1:1000 dilution). Immunodetection of proteins was revealed using tetramethylbenzidine/hydrogen peroxide (TMB/H2O2; Bangalore Genei, Bangalore, India) as substrate and resulting immunospecific bands were quantified by densitometry.

sec.title: Immunofluorescent Staining of GLUT-8 in Testis
sec.p: Bouin-fixed testes were embedded in paraffin and sectioned at a thickness of 5 µm on poly-l-lysine coated slides. After deparaffinization and rehydration, sections were washed in PBS (10 mmol/L NaH2PO4, pH 7.4 at 22°C containing 0.15 mol/L NaCl) and permeabilized in 0.2% Triton X-100 (v/v). Sections were then blocked with 10% nonimmune goat serum for 1 hour. Sections were incubated with anti-GLUT-8 (1:100 dilution each containing 1% nonimmune goat serum) antibody overnight at 4°C. After repeated rinsing with PBS, the sections were saturated with rabbit anti-goat IgG conjugated to fluorescein isothiocyanate ([FITC] 1:100 dilution containing 10% nonimmune goat serum) for 2 hours in dark. After being washed in PBS 3 to 4 times (5 minutes each), the slides were mounted and examined under the microscope (Olympus System, model CX41RF, Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Data were expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD) for 6 animals per group. Statistical analyses were performed by 1-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey posttest using SPSS (student version 7.5, SPSS Inc, UK). P < .05 was taken as statistically significant. Images were compiled using Adobe Photoshop (version 7.0, San Jose, California). Densitometric scanning was performed using Gene tool (version 3.05, Synoptics Ltd, Cambridge, UK).

sec.title: Results
Effect of BPA on Plasma Glucose, Testicular Glucose, and Insulin Levels
sec.p: Administration of BPA to adult male rats at different doses resulted in a significant increase in the levels of fasting plasma glucose when compared to controls (Figure 1A). On contrary, testicular insulin (data not shown) and glucose levels were significantly decreased in BPA-treated rats compared to controls (Figure 1B). The level of plasma insulin showed a significant dose-dependent increase on exposure to BPA (Figure 2). However, the observed effects were very prominent in the rats administered with 17β-estradiol for 45 days.

caption.p: Effect of bisphenol A (BPA) on (A) plasma glucose levels and (B) testicular glucose levels in adult rats. The values (mg/dL) are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD), n = 6 rats. *P < .05 compared with control. The 0 on the x-axis of the graph denotes control. E2 denotes 17β-estradiol (50 µg/kg bw).

Effect of bisphenol A (BPA) on plasma insulin levels in adult rats. The values (µU/mL) are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD), n= 6 rats. *P < .05 compared with control. The 0 on the x-axis of the graph denotes control. E2 denotes 17β-estradiol (50 µg/kg bw).

sec.title: Effect of BPA on H2O2 Levels in the Testis
sec.p: Exposure to BPA at various doses significantly increased the level of H2O2 in the testis of rats in a dose-dependent manner. The level of H2O2 in the estradiol-treated group was significantly higher compared to control group (Figure 3). A dose-dependent decrease in the levels of antioxidant enzymes, superoxide dismutase, and catalase was also observed (data not shown).

caption.p: Effect of bisphenol A (BPA) on hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) levels in the testis of adult rats. The values (µmol H2O2 generated/min per mg protein) are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD), n = 6 rats. *P < .05 compared with control. The 0 on the x-axis of the graph denotes control. E2 denotes 17β-estradiol (50 µg/kg bw).

sec.title: Effect of BPA on the Activities of Hexokinase and Phosphofructokinase in the Testis
sec.p: A dose-dependent decrease in the activities of glycolytic enzymes, hexokinase, and phosphofructokinase was observed in the testis of BPA-treated rats (Figure 4A and B). However, the decline in the enzyme activities was more pronounced in the testis of the estradiol-treated group.

caption.p: Effects of bisphenol A (BPA) on the activities of (A) hexokinase and (B) phosphofructokinase in the testis of adult rats. The values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD), n = 6 rats. *P < .05 compared with control. The 0 on the x-axis of the graph denotes control. E2 denotes 17β-estradiol (50 µg/kg bw).

sec.title: Effect of BPA on the Protein Levels of IRS-2 and GLUT-8 in the Testis
sec.p: Western blot analysis of IRS-2 in the testis revealed a significant dose-dependent reduction in the levels of the protein on treatment with BPA. Similarly, the levels of GLUT-8 in testis were also decreased when BPA was administered at various doses for 45 days (Figure 5). The levels of IRS-2 and GLUT-8 were significantly decreased in the estradiol-treated group.

caption.p: Alterations in the levels of insulin receptor substrate 2 (IRS-2) and glucose transporter 8 (GLUT-8) in the testis of bisphenol A (BPA)-treated rats. A, Immunoblot showing a decrease in the levels of IRS-2 and GLUT-8 proteins following treatment with BPA for 45 days. The immunoblot was probed with actin (42 kDa, bottom panel) to show equal protein loading. B, Graph representing densitometrically scanned results corresponding to A. Each data point represents the average values from 4 independent experiments normalized against the control. The 0 on the blot and x-axis of the graph denotes control. E2 denotes 17β-estradiol (50 µg/kg bw). The control was arbitrarily set at 1. *Significantly different, P < .05.

sec.title: Immunolocalization of GLUT-8 in the Testis
sec.p: Immunofluorescence was done to understand the localization of GLUT-8 protein. Immnunolocalization of GLUT-8 revealed the expression of the protein in spermatocytes and spermatids of untreated rats. However, a decrease in the expression of GLUT-8 was observed in the testis on administration with BPA. No detectable expression of GLUT-8 protein was observed in the testis of rats treated with 50 µg of 17β-estradiol (Figure 6). The images provided are representative of several fields analyzed.

caption.p: Immunofluorescent staining of glucose transporter 8 (GLUT-8) in the testis of bisphenol A (BPA)-treated rats. Representative images for GLUT-8 immunoreactivity in control (A) BPA 0.005 µg (C) BPA 0.5 µg (E) BPA 500 µg (G), and 17β-estradiol (50 µg) (I). The images (B), (D), (F), and (H) are magnified images of (A), (C), (E), and (G), respectively. A decrease in the expression of GLUT-8 protein in spermatids and spermatocytes (arrow heads) in the testis of rats exposed to BPA may be noted. The bar represents 50 µm.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the recent years, there is growing evidence associating ubiquitous exposure to environmental contaminants and increased incidence of diabetes. 30,31 Of the various environmental contaminants, compounds with estrogenic properties pose a major threat to organs which are sensitive to estrogens. 2,32 At physiological levels, estrogens carry out a plethora of functions among which maintaining the insulin sensitivity and glucose homeostasis is of prime importance. However, short-term supraphysiological administration of estradiol has been reported to have adverse effects on glucose metabolism. 33 A recent study has demonstrated the expression of glucose transporters and insulin signaling substrates in the testis of rats which emphasize the critical role of glucose in maintaining normal testicular functions. 34 In this context, we sought to investigate the effects of a well-known estrogenic compound, BPA, on the glucose metabolism and insulin signaling in the testis of adult rats. The doses selected in this study are based on the reported NOAEL (5 mg/kg per d) and TDI (10 µg/kg per d) of BPA for humans. 21

In the present study, we observed a dose-dependent increase in the levels of plasma glucose and insulin following administration with BPA and 17β-estradiol for 45 days. It has been shown that exposure of isolated pancreatic islet cells to BPA and nonylphenol promotes insulin secretion within 24 hours of exposure. 35 A potent increase in glucose level and insulin content in the β-cells of pancreas was observed when mice were injected with 100 µg/kg per d of BPA and 17β-estradiol. 5 Hence, in the present study, it is possible that the estrogenic property of BPA could have induced a state of insulin resistance resulting in simultaneous occurrence of hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia.

During the hyperglycemic conditions, excessive levels of free radicals are generated due to the overdrive of mitochondrial electron transport chain and or autooxidation of glucose. 36,37 In addition, hyperglycemia has been shown to cause inactivation and glycation of antioxidant enzymes resulting in a state of oxidative stress. 38,39 Apart from this, oxidative stress-inducing capability of BPA in various tissues including testis has been well documented. 15,16 In the present study, we observed a dose-dependent increase in the level of H2O2 following exposure to BPA for 45 days. However, it is difficult to conclude whether the observed increase in the level of H2O2 could be due to the direct influence of BPA on testis or an outcome of BPA-induced hyperglycemia or a synergistic effect.

In testis, glycolytic enzymes are present in various germ cell types and the energy requirement of the sperm for its motility is met through glycolysis. 40 It has been demonstrated that blockage of glycolysis occurs as a consequence of oxidative stress in various cells. 41,42 In the present study, we observed a significant decrease in the activities of hexokinase and phosphofructokinase, the key enzymes in the glycolytic pathway, in the testis of rats exposed to low doses of BPA. Alterations in the glycolytic flux along with the inactivation of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase were demonstrated when cultured cardiomyocytes were incubated with H2O2. 43 Therefore, in the present study, the observed inhibitory effects on glycolytic enzymes could be due to the increased level of H2O2 in the testis of rats.

Insulin plays a key role in maintaining the glucose homeostasis and thereby regulates the energy balance of the cell. Actions of insulin are mediated through receptor-mediated tyrosine phosphorylation of specific proteins known as IRSs. Expression of IRS-1 and -2 has been demonstrated in the peritubular and Sertoli cells of rat testis which signifies the role of insulin in regulating glucose uptake and energy metabolism in testis. 34 In the present study, we observed decreased level of IRS-2 protein in the testis of rats administered with BPA and estradiol. It has been reported that infusion with insulin downregulates the gene expression of IRS-1 and -2 proteins in the skeletal muscles of humans. 44 Moreover, increased levels of plasma insulin have been shown to downregulate the transcription of IRS-2 gene in the liver of rats, thereby causing hepatic insulin resistance. 45 In the present study, it is probable that BPA-induced high level of insulin could have resulted in the downregulation of IRS-2 protein. On the other hand, it has also been shown that in vitro exposure of mammalian skeletal muscle cells to low level of H2O2 results in selective loss of IRS-1 and -2 proteins through p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK)-dependent mechanism. 13 Hence, the possibility that high level of H2O2 induced by BPA could also have had an impact on IRS-2 protein cannot be ruled out.

Glucose transporter 8 is expressed in all insulin-sensitive tissues and is one of the chief glucose transporters in testis. 46 The expression of GLUT-8 in testis is considered hormonally regulated. Glucose transporter 8 has been reported to be undetectable under conditions of testicular carcinoma and estrogen treatment. 47 In the present study, immunoblotting of GLUT-8 revealed a dose-dependent decrease in the levels of this protein in the testis of BPA-treated rats. In addition, we did immunofluorescence of GLUT-8 to understand the localization of the protein which revealed that GLUT-8 is strongly expressed in spermatids and spermatocytes of control rats. However, decreased expression of GLUT-8 was observed in the testis of rats on exposure to BPA. In the present study, it is likely that estrogenic property of BPA could have resulted in the decreased expression of GLUT-8 protein in the testis. Treatment with 17β-estradiol substantially lowered the levels of GLUT-8 in the testis, which confirms the observation that expression of GLUT-8 is hormonally regulated. 47 In addition, we also observed a significant decrease in the testicular level of glucose in BPA-treated rats which could be due to the impairment of GLUT-8 in the testis. Though the testicular level of glucose is low, increased level of glucose in the circulation (hyperglycemic condition induced by BPA) could have resulted in increased generation of reactive oxygen species which, in turn, could have decreased the activities of glycolytic enzymes in testis.

In the present study, we report for the first time that oral exposure to BPA at doses well below the NOAEL and TDI levels induce a state of hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and downregulates the expression of IRS-2 and GLUT-8 in the testis of adult rats. The estrogenic and oxidative stress-inducing capacity of BPA could have contributed to the impairment of glucose homeostasis in the testis. Our findings suggest that persistent exposure to BPA may impair the testicular functions by targeting the glucose metabolism in the testis.
